# loq - Cross-Platform Log Query Tool

> LLM-friendly documentation for loq, a modern replacement for Microsoft Log Parser 2.2

## Quick Start

```bash
# Basic query
loq "SELECT * FROM data.csv WHERE status = 200"

# With input/output formats
loq -i:CSV -o:JSON "SELECT name, age FROM users.csv LIMIT 10"

# Aggregate query
loq "SELECT status, COUNT(*) FROM access.log GROUP BY status ORDER BY COUNT(*) DESC"
```

## Documentation Files

For detailed reference, see the following files in this repository:

### Main Reference (Start Here)
- [llm-docs/REFERENCE.md](llm-docs/REFERENCE.md) - Complete overview with summaries of all features

### Topic-Specific References
- [llm-docs/sql.md](llm-docs/sql.md) - SQL syntax (SELECT, JOIN, UNION, CTEs, Window Functions)
- [llm-docs/functions.md](llm-docs/functions.md) - All SQL functions (String, Math, DateTime, Aggregate)
- [llm-docs/input-formats.md](llm-docs/input-formats.md) - Input formats (CSV, JSON, W3C, EVTX, S3, etc.)
- [llm-docs/output-formats.md](llm-docs/output-formats.md) - Output formats (CSV, JSON, SQLite, Chart, etc.)
- [llm-docs/cli.md](llm-docs/cli.md) - CLI options and common patterns
- [llm-docs/dotnet.md](llm-docs/dotnet.md) - .NET bindings (Loq.Classic, Loq)
- [llm-docs/ffi.md](llm-docs/ffi.md) - C/FFI for Python, Go, Ruby, etc.

## Key Features

- **SQL-based**: Full SQL support including JOINs, UNION, CTEs, Window Functions
- **30+ Input Formats**: CSV, JSON, XML, W3C, Syslog, EVTX, S3, Parquet, etc.
- **15+ Output Formats**: CSV, JSON, SQLite, PostgreSQL, Charts, etc.
- **Cross-Platform**: Linux, macOS, Windows
- **High Performance**: 2-5x faster than MS Log Parser 2.2
- **Language Bindings**: .NET (C#), C/FFI (Python, Go, Ruby)

## Common Patterns

```sql
-- Filter and sort
SELECT * FROM logs.csv WHERE level = 'ERROR' ORDER BY timestamp DESC LIMIT 100

-- Aggregate by group
SELECT host, COUNT(*), AVG(response_time) FROM access.log GROUP BY host

-- JOIN files
SELECT a.*, b.name FROM orders.csv a JOIN customers.csv b ON a.customer_id = b.id

-- Window function
SELECT *, ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY category ORDER BY sales DESC) as rank FROM products.csv

-- CTE for complex queries
WITH errors AS (SELECT * FROM logs.csv WHERE level = 'ERROR')
SELECT source, COUNT(*) FROM errors GROUP BY source
```
